annotation.TEXT: Finally, a weapon that didn't get any nerfs to its ammo count. Anyways, Astro Crush; You press the fire button, almost every minor enemy on-screen dies. While it still only has 4 uses, it's still tremendously powerful (and now even more-so against one specific weakness affiliation).

The swimming mechanics in Aqua Man's stage were completely removed. To be honest, I don't mind this change much. This level actually plays out in a pretty standard manner now (also taking into account the structural changes made as well, for obvious reasons).
With that being said, you'll still probably want the Thunder Claw here. This is mostly because this stage's idea of "alternatives" comes in the form of disappearing blocks.

Like I said before, Homing Sniper is still pretty bad. It deals roughly the same amount of damage as a single Mega Buster shot to anything that isn't weak to it. That's not even going into the weird targeting system either, which will either home in on things you don't want it to, or circle around your intended victim in an odd pattern.

For as much as I don't like his stage, Astro Man is still probably my favorite boss in the game. His design, boss fight, and personality are all really interesting to me. I don't know why, but I really like the idea of a boss who is just actively indifferent, and clearly doesn't want to be there.

Water Balloon is somehow even worse than it was in the original. Against almost any enemy not named Sword Man, it almost universally deals 1 point of damage (even to the Fire Metools). This basically makes it the equivalent to a more limited Mega Buster that fires at a downward angle.

I would have had to forgo the weakness order in this game at some point, considering the cycle of the 4 original bosses. Search Man probably isn't the best one to start off with for the later set, especially since his weapon is still kinda bad. Regardless, I still wanted to get it as a precaution for another stage.
Oh, so we still have the maze? Yeah, something is wrong here. Either I have a slightly outdated version, or I just broke something by accident.

Aqua Man is still pretty easy, though some his attacks require a bit more effort to avoid this time (especially the water tower, which now has a wider spread). On the plus side however, Astro Crush now deals enough damage that you can actually beat him with all 4 shots.

Search Man is still a gigantic pain to deal with if you don't have the Flame Sword. His homing shots are generally annoying to avoid, and those discs don't help the situation much either. It also seems that this demake's version "Deadly Storm" is impossible to avoid if he's standing on the left or right side of the room.

Astro Man's stage generally seems to be regarded as one of the worst ones in the game, and for good reason at that. To be honest, I really like the look of this stage in general, but the actual level structure just seems to go all over the place. I realize it's intended to be an illusion with a surreal landscape, but there's SO much more you could do with that concept than what's presented here.

Speaking of level structure...while I haven't played the original Astro Man's stage in a while, I'm pretty sure the end of that first section was supposed to lead to a maze. Instead, I'm already at the sinking tower part. Not that I'm complaining, since the maze was tedious, but now I'm starting to think I have an outdated version of the game.

The hooks for the Thunder Claw are still in this stage, but are no longer necessary to complete it. A good portion of the stages for the later set of RMs got changed in that they don't require the first set's. Sometimes they'll keep the gimmicks that required those weapons, but will also add alternatives in case you don't have them.
